I'm taking this sword to the Arms show in Dallas next weekend to have it di=
sassembled by someone that knows what they are doing - I'd probably destroy=
 any value it might have - the handle seems fragile.  I have yet to see if =
the blade is signed, but figure it is and need to know the swordsmith befor=
e I know if it is junk or not.  While apart I will photo the tsuba and post=
 pictures.  The tsuba is loose right now to the extent that I can see that =
it is signed, but of coures the symbol is undecipherable to me - it is a si=
ngle charater and I can't photo it due to the angle right now.  All I know =
right now about this sword is that my one of my Husband's relatives, who wa=
s a marine in WWII, got it on Okinawa during the war.  It is obviously not =
a WWII era sword and hence the mystery and intrigue.
   
  Becky
